body:
Sent from my iPad

On Oct 18, 2012, at 9:34 AM, Ondřej Čertík notifications@github.com wrote:

> Currently I do:
> 
> 1) download the ipynb
> 2) open in gedit, copy
> 3) go to gist at github, paste, copy url
> 4) go to nbviewer.ipython.org, paste
> 
> I guess I am not quite following you.  If the nb is on the web why do you need to download it and put it into a gist?

Are you thinking there would be a publish button in the notebook ui for your own notebooks?  

Would publish upload it to gist and give you the nbviewer URL?

> It'd be nice to instead do:
> 
> 1) click publish, it will open a new tab with the notebook
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Please have a look at
http://nbviewer-dev.herokuapp.com/

I personally version control my notebook, so I just have to push.
You can also use git with gist. 

Notebook might be better integrated with versioning system later, but server need refactor. 
In particular, you want that `1) click publish,` update the currently uploaded file. So we need to kind of 'keep track' of the location.

Hi Brian, here is what I mean:

I use IPython notebook on my laptop. I create a notebook, with some calculations. Now I would like to send a link to it to my colleague. So I click File->Export->download as ipynb. Using your and @Carreau's comments I realized that I can just as well find the ipynb on my filesystem in git. Either way, I have to open it in gedit or some other editor that allows me to copy the whole file to clipboard. Then I paste it into a gist. Finally, once it is in gist, I go to the nbviewer.ipython.org and paste the gist url. At the end, I ended up with this:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/3912958/

and I am very happy with the result. My idea for huge improvement would be to only click a button in the notebook (that runs on my laptop _locally_), and it would publish it to gist and automatically load it in nbviewer.

@Carreau, I like your ideas about git. But as the first step, it can simply create a gist automatically, and simply keep updating the same gist. Github should automatically version it. If this is too complex at first, let's just create a new gist with each click on "Publish". That should be easy and ipython doesn't need to keep track of anything.

Let me know if I made myself clear.

On Thu, Oct 18, 2012 at 10:15 AM, Brian E. Granger
notifications@github.com wrote:

> Sent from my iPad
> 
> On Oct 18, 2012, at 9:34 AM, Ondřej Čertík notifications@github.com
> wrote:
> 
> > Currently I do:
> > 
> > 1) download the ipynb
> > 2) open in gedit, copy
> > 3) go to gist at github, paste, copy url
> > 4) go to nbviewer.ipython.org, paste

Based on my previous comment, that hopefully explains what I meant,
let me answer your questions:

> I guess I am not quite following you. If the nb is on the web why do you
> need to download it and put it into a gist?

The IPython Notebook is running on my laptop locally. But even if I
served it on the web somewhere, I think it wouldn't change anything. I
need to download it, and put it into gist, so that I can give it to
nbviewer (I think that nbviewer only accepts gists).

> Are you thinking there would be a publish button in the notebook ui for
> your own notebooks?

Yes, exactly.

> Would publish upload it to gist and give you the nbviewer URL?

Exactly. It would simply open a new browser tab with the nbviewer page, so that I can see it and copy the URL myself from the browser's address bar.

Ondrej

If I understand you correctly, it is really a "publish as gist" button.  I
think Stefan had a draft of that working, but then github changed its
authentication model.  Obviously, the other alternative is for you to
version control the entire directory on github as a regular repo and then
simply push to update the notebook.  But I agree we need to improve the
sharability of notebooks and that a publish as gist would help.  We also
envision storing the gist id in the notebook metadata so that people could
always trace it back to the gist.

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

Actually, what I want is "publish into nbviewer", that will load the current notebook in nbviewer in a new tab, so that I can check that it looks good and then copy the URL and send it to my collaborators.

But even just "publish as gist" would be a huge step forward and obviously a necessary first step anyway. 

Btw, I thought that the nbviewer has its own database of notebooks, that are loaded from gist. But by your comments and looking into the nbviewer sources, it now seems to me, that the nbviewer just reads the gist on the fly whenever I access a given url at nbviewer.python.org and just "pretty prints the JSON", correct? That's very clever, I didn't realize this.

On Thu, Oct 18, 2012 at 11:49 AM, Ondřej Čertík notifications@github.comwrote:

> Actually, what I want is "publish into nbviewer", that will load the
> current notebook in nbviewer in a new tab, so that I can check that it
> looks good and then copy the URL and send it to my collaborators.

OK I think that would be easy to do once the publish to gist is done.

> But even just "publish as gist" would be a huge step forward and obviously
> a necessary step anyway.
> 
> Btw, I thought that the nbviewer has its own database of notebooks, that
> are loaded from gist. But by your comments and looking into the nbviewer
> sources, it now seems to me, that the nbviewer just read the gist on the
> fly whenever I access a given url at nbviewer.python.org and just "pretty
> prints the JSON", correct? That's very clever, I didn't realize this.
> 
> Yes that is exactly how it works.
> 
> —

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

> We also envision storing the gist id in the notebook metadata
> Ah ! I always forgot that notebook have metadata also and not only cells....
> 
> Btw, I thought that the nbviewer has its own database of notebooks, that are loaded from gist. But by your comments and looking into the nbviewer sources, it now seems to me, that the nbviewer just reads the gist on the fly whenever I access a given url at nbviewer.python.org and just "pretty prints the JSON", correct? That's very clever, I didn't realize this.

Any Url actually. Gist are just a special case. (there is a 10min cache though) 

> http://penandpants.com/2012/10/10/open-in-nbviewer-chrome-extension/

and now, there is the bookmarklet for any browser.
http://penandpants.com/2012/10/16/open-in-nbviewer-bookmarklet/

I've contacted the author, who just fixes a small bug in https and will add a link to it on nbviewer website.

Thanks to jist https://github.com/ConradIrwin/jist, I just do:

!jist -p notebook_name.ipynb

to publish a gist.  With that problem solved, the rest is super easy.

Here's a notebook that publishes itself as a gist and opens nbviewer on
that gist in a new tab (the notebook itself made the gist):

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/3914598

(note that nbviewer won't work while GitHub is working out its current DDOS
attack)

-MinRK

When we worked on this earlier, we got stuck on OAuth, but since then GitHub has made available their authorizations API:

http://developer.github.com/v3/oauth/#oauth-authorizations-api

This would allow us to do Gists attached to your username.

To do what @certik wants using anonymous gists is trivial to add, only then you can't update the notebook without creating another gist.

Just to note: tools/gh_api.py includes a function to post a gist either
anonymously or using OAuth:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/tools/gh_api.py#L71

Haha, thanks, I knew that code had to be around somewhere!

I would be very happy if we can stick it to the menu somewhere, probably File, and it would create anonymous gist and open a new tab with nbviewer. After this works, it can be iteratively improved.
@stefanv, would you know how to finish my PR? I got stuck, see the PR for details.

OK let's continue the discussion on the PR.

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
@minrk has a %gist magic in [his ipython_extensions](https://github.com/minrk/ipython_extensions) repo, FWIW.

Yes, but min's extension require the gem, and assume the kernel run in the ipynb directory.
and actually execute code on kernel side, which should not append if we bundle it.
Right - a real implementation would have to be pure javascript in the browser.  My gist (like all of my extensions) are simple toys, and just for personal use.
My [extension](https://github.com/minrk/ipython_extensions/tree/master/nbextensions/gist.js) is now pure-js, and works on IPython master.
